I am not sure if someone posted this article here before, but it is an interesting read, so I am putting it anyway.

Short version: Dropbox became so big, they had to move out of Amazon Cloud.

The article is a long read, but it sheds a lot of light on what leaders of the cloud think of the move.
posts.caption: wired.com
posts.description: Half-a-billion people stored files on Dropbox. Well, sort of. Really, the files were in Amazon’s cloud. Until Dropbox built its own. And threw the switch.

posts.caption: blog.wearecolony.com
posts.description: Dropping the trusted workhorse from our front-end back in 2014 has led to a faster, leaner platform

posts.message:
I have a question for guys who know about SEO (search engine optimization). What is the best way to know which search engine is the source of the visit?
For example, I have a website and I want to recognize the clicks that come from a specific website (i.e. google) to know the effectiveness of ads for a given platform vs the other
What is the best place to do that?
I looked it up, some people say it could be done by placing some metadata on the SEO listing itself but I never have done that before and not sure if it could be done this way or not?

SitePoint is selling 6 licenses of TemplateMonster's #WordPress Monstroid theme for $39 total instead of $79 per site 

I did a bit of research on this template (usefulness and pricing) and found it more interesting than I originally thought. Might be useful for WordPress freelancers.
